speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in Case 10-680, Howes v. Fields. Mr. Bursch.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Don't you think being in custody itself is a circumstance?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What's all this "all-circumstances missed"?  I thought that our case law was fairly clear that all circumstances is a test for voluntariness.  I thought the issue has always been under Miranda:  Is the person free to go or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, since when have we imported of the language of voluntariness into the Miranda test?  And should we be creating yet another test?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So, go to the test of freedom to leave.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: You're taken from your cell and locked into a room -- and let's change the facts --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- and locked in a room and said:  Talk to me; tell me.  You have to tell me what happened. Is that person free to go.Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: All right.  So, what makes this case different?  He's taken from a -- except being told that he could leave.  If he had been taken from his cell, removed from the prison, his normal setting, taken by armed guards to another building and, with guards at the door, sat down and told talk to us about this incident, why would he think he was free to leave?  There is one fact I'm taking out of it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Which is that he was told he was free to go.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: There -- as I see the record, he claims twice he said, I don't want to talk to you.  And when he asked to leave at the end, it took 20 minutes, and they continued the questioning.  Doesn't that counter the rest of what you're saying?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why is a per se rule necessarily what is being argued here?  For one thing, he had no choice but to go with the police, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So, it's different from some cases where the prisoner initiates the conversation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And it doesn't make any difference that they -- they took him from his cell, he was under compulsion to leave with them and interrogated during the hours when prisoners are ordinarily sleeping?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: General, when you say that, I took sometimes your brief and the U.S. Government's brief to be saying something more, which is that it's not all the circumstances; it's all the circumstances minus circumstances that are attendant upon normal prison living. So, are you still arguing that, or are you really arguing an all-the-circumstances test?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: So, a court can still think -- when it's doing an all-the-circumstances inquiry, it can still factor in something like, you know, it just -- it was going to take him an hour to get back to his cell.  That's still something that the court can consider along with everything else.  Is that right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, which way do you think that factor cuts?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Except when they say you have to leave, one way to interpret that or to analyze that might be to say:  You're in custody no matter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And when you say you have to leave, that's almost coercion -- coercive of them to say, because he doesn't want to have to go back to the cell.Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But I think it makes your case weaker, not stronger, that statement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The Chief asked you, in his question, which way does it cut?  Meaning you seemAlderson Reporting Company to be advocating a rule that says merely because he's in prison is irrelevant, standing alone.  I think your adversary is saying you can't take out the fact that this person's liberty is restrained from the equation. So, going back to my hypothetical, if you're forced to leave the prison, as this gentleman was, and put in another room, what presumption should you start with?  Shouldn't the presumption be that if you're forced to go to another place, that you are in custody?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What -- what would make someone who is forced to go somewhere think that they're free to go back, absent being told?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But let's -- what wouldAlderson Reporting Company make any reasonable prisoner who can't move without an escort believe that they're always free to go back?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Once they're forced to go from point A to point B.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Ms. Anders.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose the policeman had said:  I'm taking you away with me for 20 minutes, period.  Takes him away, puts him in a place, asks him questions for 20 minutes.  All right?  Does he have to Mirandize him?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, those are the totality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I just gave you the totality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, no.  I'm taking you to a special room, and in this special room, I'm going to ask you questions for 20 minutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There's no other circumstance.  That's it.  Everything else is the same as here, except he added those words.  Now what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Not in custody.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He's only going to be there for 20 minutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: He would have thought heAlderson Reporting Company could leave after 20 minutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, outside -- we walk outside, there's a policeman in the street, and he says to someone who's a suspect:  Come with me; I'm taking you to jail; I'm going to ask you questions for 20 minutes.  He takes him to a barred room; he can't get out for 20 minutes.  He has to Mirandize him?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What's the difference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Could I ask you a different sort of question, Ms. Anders?  Putting aside what the Sixth Circuit did here, if you look back at the initial State court opinion, do you read the State court -- do you think the State court is fairly read, could the Sixth Circuit have fairly read it, as establishing its own per se rule, which was the per se rule we rejected in Mathis?  In other words, that the State supreme court required some kind of nexus between the prison custody and the interrogation?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, you're going back to confusing coercion issues with custody issues, and I don't know that you have really answered Justice Breyer's question.  Someone's picked off the street and told you have to go into this room, and questions are asked.  Wouldn't we assume that that person is in custody?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, but he didn't choose to go to that room.  He was placed in that room. What makes him think that if -- if his jailers areAlderson Reporting Company walking him somewhere, that he's free to leave?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: If he were out and the police officer said, come along with us, he could say no.  But here he didn't -- he didn't have that choice.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Is it -- is the time relevant, that this was done -- they took him away at 7:00 in the evening and kept him for 7 hours?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, they -- that didn't do him any good, because he couldn't get back to his cell without being escorted there.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, I wonder why you just agreed that the 7 hours would be a pertinent circumstance.  It strikes me that that would be a pertinent circumstance on overall voluntariness, perhaps, but once you're told you can leave whenever you want, I don't see why it matters at all how long he's kept there.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So, it's not a relevant circumstance on the custody question.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Now Ms. Jacobs.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it certainly -- it certainly doesn't mean he can leave the prison, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's clear, but -- but isn't that the only difference?  It, certainly, at a minimum, means that he can leave this interrogation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But what could it possibly mean if it didn't mean you could leave this room where you're now being questioned?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What is the rule that you want us to adopt?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, everybody in prison is in custody --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- at all times.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, if you want to question anybody in prison about anything --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- you have to give a Miranda warning.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What sense does that make? Why is one more in custody depending on the subject that the police want to question the person about?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, whenever they -- whenever a prisoner is isolated and questioned about a crime, no matter where it occurs, a Miranda warning has to be given?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: About a possible crime?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, how is that consistent with the totality of the circumstances test that we've always insisted upon in Miranda cases?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, if a prisoner is stabbed in the yard and there are 50 prisoners in the yard at the time and the prison guards want to question everybody to see what they saw, they all have to be given Miranda warnings?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: No, no.  No, no, that's not the way Miranda works.  Miranda suppresses a statement that is adverse to the person who was questioned.  And the police doesn't know when the adverse statement's going to come.  So, you're running away from the hypothetical.  It just doesn't work.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If it's a witness in the outside world, the witness is unlikely to be in custody.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: It does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, these -- all these people in your view are in custody, and they all are being asked questions that may incriminate them --

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: -- and they don't have to be given Miranda warnings unless they're suspects.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And when will that not occur?  In my hypothetical of the stabbing in the yard, you mean that you think the guards are going to say: Okay, all you guys stay here; now we're all -- we're going to question each of you individually with everybody else, the 49 other prisoners present.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And then they'll be isolated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: So, they all will get Miranda warnings.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: And where do you get this focus on isolation from?  I mean, it's never mentioned in Mathis.  You said let's go back to Mathis, but that's not a part of Mathis, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought that there was no discussion of the "in custody" point in Mathis.  It was assumed that they were in custody, and the issue was whether he could be questioned about a crime other than the one for which he was being held.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, Justice Ginsburg is quite right.  That -- that was not the issue in Mathis.  The argument in Mathis was:  We're questioning him about something else; so, we don't have to give him Miranda warnings.  And that's the question that the Court decided.  I don't think it had any discussion about whether -- there was certainly not the argument of whether he was in custody or not.  The argument was this is a different crime; so, we don't have to give you Miranda. And the Court rejected that.  So how doesAlderson Reporting Company that clearly establish the law on which the court relied in this case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you know where exactly in Mathis?  It's only --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- about five pages long.  Can you show me where they have that discussion about custody, as opposed to a discussion about what crime is being discussed?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Exactly.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Exactly.  It's implied.  Inferred.  How --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is that clearly established law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Well, do you agree --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Do you agree that this is not -- what you want to derive from Mathis is not part of the holding of Mathis?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's an extension.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought you were going back to Miranda itself, which says in custody or otherwise deprived of his freedom of action in anyAlderson Reporting Company significant way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So -- and I think you repeated the phrase from -- from Miranda that what the Court was aiming at was incommunicado interrogation of an individual in a police-dominated atmosphere.  The question is whether the Court has modified what Miranda said in -- in that regard.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: This Court, this Court, because this Court now seems to assume that it must be in custody and not -- not otherwise deprived of action, that being in custody is essential.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes, I think you did.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm not sure you answered mine from before.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: How do you think that your argument or the decision of the court below was implicit in or an extension of Mathis?  Mathis says you don't -- you're not free of Miranda just because it's a different crime.  How does that answer the issue before the Sixth Circuit in this case?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I thought what we've been arguing about is not the nexus issue, but instead whether, in light of the circumstances or under an absolute rule, there's custody.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And what is the clearly established law set forth in our cases that answers that latter question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Can I ask you this?  Suppose you have this situation:  The police officers go to a prison.  The -- a prisoner is brought to an interview room, and the police officers are there with the prisoner in the interview room.  And they say to him: We're investigating allegations that you committed child abuse.  Now, you're free to leave if you want to, and we'll see that you go back to your cell right away.  He says, no, no, I want to explain this; I welcome this opportunity to speak to you. Do they have to give him Miranda warnings.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, their question -- the question is, is the person entitled to Miranda warnings?  And the argument has been that they're not entitled to Miranda warnings unless you're in custody. They say:  You want to have a per se rule for in custody; that is, if you're taken out of your cell and put in another place under police guard and questioned.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, they said:  We'd like to talk to you about it, but you don't have to talk to us; you're free to go.  And he says immediately:  No, no, there's a misunderstanding here; I want to explain this; I am glad you came and asked me about this; I don't want to go back to my cell. And you say that's coercive.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Can I -- since we're talking about the Sixth Circuit decision, what it says is -- this is on page 10a.  "The central holding of Mathis is that a Miranda warning is required whenever an incarcerated individual is isolated from the general prison population and interrogated, i.e., questioned in a manner likely to lead self-incrimination about conduct occurring outside of the prison."  Is that correct --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: -- description of Mathis?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I thought Mathis rejected the argument that it depends on whether the crime is the one that you're in prison for or something else.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well -- the first part, "a Miranda warning is required whenever an incarcerated individual is isolated from the general prison population" -- okay -- "and interrogated"; i.e., questioned in a manner or whatever.  Now, does that address all of the issues?  Is that -- where in Mathis is the discussion about whenever an incarcerated individual is isolated from the general prison population?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No, no.  Where in Mathis?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: If the argument wereAlderson Reporting Company Miranda was not required because this -- this concerns a different crime than what you're in prison for here.  I understand the idea that -- under AEDPA, that Mathis is clearly established law.  The issue here, however, as the Sixth Circuit put it, is a warning is required whenever an incarcerated individual is isolated from the general prison population.  And I just don't see that anywhere in Mathis.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And what you infer is the rule that incarceration constitutes custody.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that is --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that is Shatzer, and Shatzer was careful to say we've never decided that issue.Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it states in broader terms.  It says we've never decided whether incarceration constitutes custody for Miranda purposes and, indeed, have explicitly declined to address the issue.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It talks about Bradley, which was definitely where the issue was.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: Ms. Jacobs, wouldn't it be fair to say -- it seems to be me that Shatzer -- excuse me.  Mathis must have found that Mr. Mathis -- the Court in Mathis must have found that Mr. Mathis was in custody.  That would be a fair inference for Mathis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But we have no idea why the Court thought that Mr. Mathis was in custody.  That wasn't at issue in the case.  The Court doesn't talk about any of the surrounding factual circumstances. There might have been a thousand things we don't know about that led everybody to assume that was -- led everybody to assume that Mr. Mathis was in custody, not the particular things that the Sixth Circuit mentioned.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Isn't the best you can say, not that Mathis found but perhaps that Mathis apparently assumed that he was in custody, because there is no discussion of it? There's no discussion of the custody.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, they give you a factual recital.  He was in his cell and all that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: But we don't know why they thought Mathis was in custody.  It just wasn't an issue in the case.  Everybody had assumed it.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What's dicta?  Dicta is something that's said that's not necessary to the holding.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We don't have anything that's said about it here.Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There's no indication that he told -- that he told the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- officers that he needed medication.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The Ohio court -- or the -- I'm sorry.  The court below had its own -- seemingly had its own absolute rule --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: -- that if you're told you're free to go, that that breaks the chain of custody, whatever that might mean.  Assuming -- and the Sixth Circuit said if you are removed from the prison and questioned, you absolutely must be given warnings. Is there a middle ground, and what would that middle ground be?  And what would be -- how would that middle ground affect the outcome of this case?Alderson Reporting Company

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, you -- you mentioned several times, we were talking about Mathis, that, you know, they mentioned he was in -- in a cell, right?  I've just been skimming it quickly.  I don't see where that's mentioned.  Do you know offhand?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And I --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I did, too.  And -- well, I'll look at it again.  I'm sure --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sure it's there. All I see is noting that he was in prison serving a State sentence, but --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Okay.  Let me --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Bursch, you have 6 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
